newsitem.title: USA: Clintons "very concerned" about Harriman condition.
newsitem.headline: Clintons "very concerned" about Harriman condition.

text.p: U.S. President Bill Clinton and his wife Hillary are "very concerned" about Pamela Harriman, the U.S. ambassador to France who suffered a brain haemorrhage on Monday evening, and have asked to be kept informed of her condition, the White House said on Tuesday.

"The president and the first lady were very concerned to hear about Ambassador Harriman's condition," White House spokesman Mike McCurry told reporters. "They've asked to be kept updated for any information that comes from our embassy in Paris. Obviously, she is in their thoughts and prayers."
McCurry declined comment on Harriman's medical codition.
In Paris, a U.S. embassy spokesman said on Tuesday that Harriman was in serious condition in the American Hospital of Paris after suffering a brain haemorrhage on Monday evening.
Harriman, 76, a close supporter of Clinton, was taken ill at the Ritz Hotel where she had gone for a swim and she was taken to hospital by ambulance.

"The initial diagnosis is that the ambassador suffered a cerebral haemorrhage. She remains in serious condition," a U.S. embassy spokesman said in a brief statement read to reporters outside the hospital in the Paris suburb of Neuilly.
